I don't know if I can still have sex.  I'm not a young man anymore, doctor. And I'm a little bit scared. Truth be told, I'm a lot scared.  What's today?  Six years.  Aaaaaah, freak out! Le freak, c'est chic .. Aaaah, freak out! Feet slapping in the soapy water, he performs a nifty disco move.  This is it.  If she dies, she dies. He leaves. Sonny sprints into the courtyard.  I have seen the top of the mountain. And it is good. Graham nods, sits down next to him. They gaze out at the waking city.  A man... .?  Carry on.  Top of the mountain.  Rather special. He leaves. Madge just stares after him.  Good evening, the Ainslies. Douglas and Jean are approaching them.  Turning left?   Two should fit us all, I think.  I'd rather not go back at all. A voice comes behind them. Carol has come out of the courtyard.  Ready?  We're moving in together.  So I'm not clear now. Am I staying or going?  I'd like to.  I sleep in the trees.
dialogues.Graham: Bloody retirement parties. Hard cheese, soft wine, and endless speeches. Why do people do that? No one ever said about any kind of party: it was a wonderful occasion, just a shame that the speeches were so short.  One day very soon.  This is the day. Everyone looks round at him. He's almost as surprised as they are that he's spoken out loud.  This is the day. He turns and walks out.  D'you want these books?  Mrs Megson! His cleaner, MRS MEGSON, comes in.  I want you to have this.  Absolutely. There's a slight crack on the bottom. But I think you might know something about that already. Mrs Megson goes.  I used to live there. A long time ago.     Alright. Plan B.   The bus will drop us in the centre of town. We can take tuk- tuks the rest of the way! They follow him through the hordes. And see their bus. It's absolutely rammed. People are practically hanging out of the windows.  It's time to prove the first and only rule of India: there's always room. He starts to fight his way to the door. Evelyn's at the back. She stops, for a moment, looks around her.  Forty years.  I'm sorry.  God, don't ask me. I'm more scared than you are. They both smile, sit in silence for a bit.  Yes. I think it's going to be extraordinary.     This can't be right, surely?  But there were houses all along here . these were homes.  No. That'll do for now. Thank you. He hands over some money, and Pravesh pedals away. Graham turns to look at the boys playing cricket. One of them, SANJAY, is batting.  Excuse me. There used to be  And the people? The families?  Don't grip so tightly with your right hand. Sanjay looks puzzled.  On the bat. The right is just a guide. Keep your left elbow high, play down the line of your arm, and then you'll hit through     Come on. Do your worst. They're both enjoying the banter, as Sanjay heads back to the beginning of his run-up, then turns and sprints in to bowl. As Graham watches Sanjay running towards him, Sanjay seems to slow, his movements becoming sluggish, never seeming to reach the crease. He looks at the faces of the other boys, frozen, waiting. The ball seems to take forever to leave Sanjay's hand. Graham steps back, completely fails to play a stroke, and is bowled.  Yes. Yes, I'm fine.  Mrs Ainslie. I hope you had a good day. What did you get up to?  Why would you not go out? There's so much to see. Jean had hoped for some appreciation of her wit, and is floored by his question. She can hardly understand, let alone tell him, the depths of her discomfort.  Open your eyes, Mrs Ainslie. All life is here, I tell you. Jean stares at him. He goes on through the archway into the hotel. Then stops.  I could talk to the chef, if you like. Perhaps get you some grilled chicken, plain rice.  Good evening.  I'd rather hear about yours.  A role I'm sure you'll perform with great distinction. He's about to inquire further, when Evelyn sees Douglas and Jean emerge from their room.  I'm flattered you shared it with me. He turns to greet the new arrivals.  Good evening, the Ainslies.  Well, I've just finished telling Mrs Greenslade all about it. Evelyn registers the lie, but says nothing.  I talked to the chef for you. He said it will be no problem.  Goodnight to you. He seems about to say something else. She waits for a moment, then walks on.  Mrs Greenslade?  Can I show you something?     I grew up here. Just a short drive away. It was a big house, and we had servants, everyone did. We knew their wives, their children. One boy, Manoj, became my friend. We played a lot of cricket together, played anything we could. And that's how it stayed for years. Until one night, he became something more. We had a few months, we had that. There was a weekend in Udaipur, we sat by a lake and watched the sun go down, and I remember thinking . I will never be this happy again. And I was right. Because quite suddenly it was over. We'd fallen asleep, and they found us.      And now I think .. what if I am the last person on earth he wants to see? Evelyn says nothing.  I don't think I can go through with it.  Yes. Yes. Oh yes.  She won't speak English. She's what used to be called an Untouchable. An outcast, born below society. To a good Hindu, even her shadow is polluted. He greets Anokhi in Hindi, and heads for the door.  I don't think so. I'm gay. Although nowadays more in theory than practice. Good day. He leaves. A moment later, Jean comes rushing out. Immediately she realises two things; first, that Graham has already gone. And second, that Muriel is watching her.  Good morning.  Yes, you did say that. You did.  I'll try not to come in tomorrow.  Good evening. Muriel nods at him, and he goes on into his room. A moment later, Jean sits down next to Muriel.  But I've filled out that form. I've given it to you. Many times.  But it's the same enquiry I make every day.  Mrs Ainslie... .?  Unutterable beauty. Everywhere. In the light, the colours, the smiles, the people who see life as a privilege not a right, and so teach me something every day. The waiter brings their tea.  It'll be fine. The waiter goes.  It's a pleasant surprise to see you out and about.  Yes. That's progress. Where were you going?    I'm gay. She stares at him. Beat.  I'm not embarrassed. Jean smiles wanly, grateful for his lie.  I'd love to take you. Perhaps - He breaks off. Douglas and Jean have come in. Jean looks rather desperate.  Good evening, Mrs Ainslie. Please allow me. He pulls a chair out for her. She shoots him a look of passionate gratitude for his exquisite sensitivity.  What is it, Sonny?  That is great news. What are working?  Well, congratulations.  It's a false alarm. There's no way they could find anything in that office. They probably just picked an address at random, just to keep me off their backs. I'm sure that's what happened. It's going to be nothing. Don't you think it's going to be nothing?  Yes. Yes I should. Yes.  I'm sorry to disturb you so late. My name is Graham Dashwood. A long time ago I -  I am afraid I don't know you.  (after a fraction of a  How did it go? Norman turns, to see Graham standing above him.  I saw someone yesterday, a man I hadn't seen for many years. A man I've loved all my life. Norman is a bit startled by this.  Yes.   I didn't know how he'd been in the meantime, didn't want to guess. I brought disgrace upon him and his family, and imagined he might hate me for it. But we talked all night. He's been happy. He's led a peaceful life, married to a woman who understood him and loved him nonetheless. But he's never forgotten me. That's what he said. I asked his forgiveness anyway. He said he had nothing to forgive me for. That instead I should forgive myself. All that time. All that time I believed I'd sentenced him to a life of shame. When I was the one in prison. But not any more. Silence for a while.  Yes. Norman smiles, then stands and goes on inside. Graham settles back into his chair, looks out at the world.  Not any more.
dialogues.Jean: What if we fell somewhere else?  It's just that we might not manage to plan our sudden fall in the exact corner where the button is.  And would it be possible to get the rail to go through the middle of the room as well?  To help us get across, not just around?  Thirty years in the Civil Service and this is all we can afford?  No. But try it anyway.     Obviously one's read one's Kipling, but we view this as an opportunity to explore another culture, as well as making new friends. And a retired judge is just the class of guest one was hoping for, isn't it Douglas?  You don't seem like an experienced traveller.  Of course it's a good idea. Who can you trust if not a High Court Judge?  Douglas, these are not words that often pass my lips, but you may actually be right. The country seems to be rather more civilised than one originally thought.  Are you insane? "Avoid all food not from a reputable vendor, it will have been washed with impure water." Douglas keeps eating, with great enjoyment.  Marvellous. Then I'll have the ham, cheese, and streptococcus, please. Or perhaps the bacteria, lettuce and tomato. Douglas turns to Muriel.  I want to stay at the other hotel, the one in the brochure.  You've Photoshopped it!  What will start to make this alright is for you to give us a refund.  You will? Straight away?  So the upshot is that he's spent all our money getting us here, and we can't leave till he's made some more. Muriel has arrived at her table.     I'm your wife. Have we met?  Given the alternative, yes.  Because you give them money.  Good evening, Your Honour.  Well, I started in my bedroom, where I had a lovely couple of hours giving all the cockroaches names. Then after a lunch that will long have a place in my heartburn, I came out here and stared blindly at a book waiting for someone - anyone to rescue me. And how glad I am it was you.  I would appreciate that very much. Graham goes on in. Jean just sits there. Wishing he'd come back out again.  So spiritual, I bet you hardly noticed the smell of elephant dung.  Yes, where do you get to every day?  I'm sure she wouldn't mind hearing it again. She waits. But Graham is as elusive as he is tactful.  Did you hear that, Douglas? Plain grilled food; manna from heaven.        Good morning. Muriel says nothing.  Lovely day. Still nothing from Muriel.  Lovely. Lovely. She turns and goes back in. Muriel thinks for a while, then turns to Anokhi.  You know where he goes. I know you know. But you won't tell me. Muriel says nothing.  I can get Hobnobs out here, you know. I know a way. As many as you want. Milk or plain. Long pause.  Thank you.     Will you check in at the bank? Douglas emerges from the bathroom.  Why do you ask that every morning?  I didn't sleep a wink. The tap in there never stops dripping.  What did he say?  I wish I could say the same.     I don't know how you can bear this country. What do you see that I don't?  Is this milk pasteurized?  But that's not true, is it? You're just lying to me right now  Is it? She looks at him.  To the bank. I . was going to the bank. Not that there's any reason to think something has changed. But our daughter, you see, she did promise, and one does try to remain optimistic. One has to. Otherwise    Oh god. Is it possible you feel the same? She brings his hand to her mouth, kisses it.  The way you talk to me. Your compassion, your understanding .. the wonderful, tender consideration, it had to be more than just -  As in ... happy? Graham says nothing. Jean lets go of his hand.  Yes. I see. Of course I see. The ghastly inappropriateness of it all settles on them both.  I appear to have humiliated myself. And embarrassed you.  Like I said. This country is driving me mad. Shall we go?        I can't stay in this country a moment longer.            . we should never have come. This whole trip is a grotesque fantasy. It's time to go home. Jean starts to pack. Irrationally, compulsively.   Look at us. A group of self- deluding old fossils traipsing around as if it's our bloody gap year. Humiliating ourselves     Yes, well. When I want your opinion, I'll give it to you.  You're very kind. But I rather think I'll turn in early. Goodnight everyone. She goes into her room.  Mrs Greenslade, might I have my husband back now? They spring apart.  Douglas? She walks off back into the room. Douglas turns to Evelyn.     Spare me your explanations. D'you think I'm jealous?  You were already doing a perfectly good job of embarrassing yourself. Can you imagine how ghastly it's been for everyone to watch you mooning around after that simpering doe- eyed ex-housewife, taking advantage of her loneliness and -  I checked my emails. This came. She hands him a piece of paper.  We're particularly well. Douglas, tell them our news. She looks to him, waits. He says nothing. So she turns, and smiles.  We're going home.  The whole thing is actually tremendously exciting. Not just getting on a plane, but getting on a plane and turning left.  First class. And home in time for our 40th wedding anniversary. We haven't yet decided how to mark the occasion.  Thank you. Evelyn turns, and walks away.       Douglas?  If you say one more word, I'll kill you with my thumbs.  This is ridiculous. It could go on for hours. There's no way we're ever going to get out of here.  You. Can you get us to the airport?  I'll give you everything I have.  Come on, Douglas. Come on! Douglas gets the suitcases out of the trunk of the cab.   What?   How about if I give you something else? My watch?  No.  He can do one person, and cases.  Could fate find a better way to tell us what we need to hear?  That it's over. It was over a long long time ago.  I have to go, Douglas.  No, you'll want to come after me. Chase me to the airport and tell me everything will be fine. But please don't. Because the truth is we both deserve more than we've had. You're just too kind and too loyal to admit it.  I will be alright. I'm turning left. She climbs onto the rickshaw. As the drumming intensifies, Douglas stands holding his suitcase, watching her weave through the traffic and out of sight.
dialogues.Muriel: Listen, young lady. I want a cup of tea, and I want it now.  How hard d'you have to fall down before you get some proper attention? Hours I've been lying here, and not a single doctor has come to see me.  That one? She looks up to the far end of the ward, where a doctor is washing his hands. He's black.  He can wash all he likes, that colour's not coming out. I want an English doctor.  Easy for you to say, you're not having it.  I'm not getting it from you. 2nd Green Revisions I0/01/11 10.  Not any of your lot.  So when do I have the operation?  At my age, I can't plan that far ahead. I don't even buy green bananas.  Is it local?  You know who'll be there, don't you? Indians. Loads of them, A sea of brown faces and black hearts, all greasy haired and reeking of spices. Never see one on their own, do you? No, becuase they hunt in packs. All the better to rob me blind and -  You're supposed to see me into my flat. That's what they said.  No good moaning to me, mate. You married her! But he's gone. Muriel wheels herself on over the bumpy ground.  PG Tips. Brown sauce. Ten jars of Marmite. Thirty one packets of Chocolate Hobnobs. Pickled onions. Pickled eggs. And pickle.  What does that mean?  If anyone asks, say you're my mother. I don't want people to think we're together.  In your dirty dreams.  If I can't pronounce it, I'm not eating it. The cacophony of horns continues. Jean screams, as another collision looms.  There's an Indian in there! Graham smiles, goes on into his room. Which is dusty, but comfortable and pleasant. He looks around with satisfaction.  My what?  You're not touching me.  Have you got a marker pen on you?  I want to mark it. So you don't take the wrong hip.  Hell. I'm in hell.  When can I go back to England?  They must have got lucky.         Kill me. Kill me now. Sonny steers Mr Maruthi towards the reception, speaks quietly.     You won't get the dirt out like that. Anokhi just smiles at her radiantly.  I worked in service for years, looked after a lovely house. I kept it spotless. You need a bit more pressure on that brush. Graham walks past, on his way out.  Where d'you go every day? Is it a woman? Nip round there for a curry and a bit of afters?  Long old life, isn't it?  Public Records Office.  Where's this? Where are we?  What happened to my usual route?  You didn't tell me.  How soon can I leave?  I haven't been kind.  I'm not eating that.  I'd still rather a Scotch Egg. Then she sees something through the open doorway: the children have turned her wheelchair on its side and are spinning the wheels. She's on her feet in a flash.  Get off! Get off it, you dirty thieving bastards! Several terrified faces turn. One little girl starts to cry. Everyone is staring at Muriel.  I didn't see. They were playing. I'm sorry. I'm sorry        Glad to meet her family. Her grandmother. Her kids. Ajit translates. Anokhi speaks.  I looked after somebody else's. Ajit translates.  This one family, years I was with them. I ran the house, looked after the money, did it all, cared for them like they were my own. Ajit starts to translate. But Muriel doesn't wait.  That's the mistake, see. You don't want to get like that, to start feeling part of something. One day they decided I needed some help. I was grateful, I tried to teach her. Not just the books, but how to crisp up the bacon like the gentleman preferred it, the way the little one liked to have her hair brushed. The things you only know if you care. But then they said I was no longer useful to them. Thanked me for my service. As if that's all it was. I got a flat in the end. I'm the only one in the building not a foreigner. More Indians there than here! But before I came to this place, my biggest problem was what to do with all the time I had. Because that flat's so small, I can have the whole place spotless in half an hour. And then what am I supposed to do for the rest of the day? There's silence for a bit. Then Ajit speaks.  Give her these. Ajit hands Anokhi what Muriel gave him: a packet of Chocolate Hobnobs. This time it's Muriel who cannot meet Anokhi's eye. Tries to hide her desire to leave. Ajit turns her chair and pushes her away. Over this, the sound of singing  So there's a process, they call it pickling. I have no idea what it is, or how they do it, but whoever invented it was a smart man. But the real genius was the one who introduced an onion into the system. That I could never have thought of. Ajit looks at her, ready to translate.  No, forget it. Muriel is looking out at the yard. She sees Mrs Kapoor, talking to some surveyors. They're mapping out the building. Mrs Kapoor sees Muriel watching her, comes over to them.  I'm helping her clean. If these pots get any dirtier, you'll have to serve the food with penicillin.        Depends. Do you know how to use a computer?  Mrs Ainslie said she had an address where I could get some things I need. Some biscuits. She said I could get them on the line.  Do you want him to see you?  She's not back yet. Douglas stops. Beat.  Where d'you think you're going?  Already?  Doesn't have to. Silence. Everyone stares at Muriel. She takes out the spreadsheets.  I've been going over the accounts.  What he said to me, I imagine. She turns to Sunaina.  Can you help?  Depends how you read the accounts.  Turns out the original plan is good, it works. Just not in the hands of an imbecile.  What the place needs is more money.  He's reconsidered.  So long as there is someone to help the manager.        You're off your game. Lost your confidence, maybe. But you're a thoroughbred. You'll be back. Madge smiles.  And what about you, Mrs Greenslade? Evelyn has come down, unnoticed by all. Except Muriel.  We haven't talked much, you and  Most things don't. But sometimes what happens instead is the good stuff.  Haven't you got work in the morning? Evelyn nods.  Besides, he'll be back.  50,000 rupees says I'm right. At your current salary that should take you three months to pay off. Muriel stands up. Everybody stares. She starts to walk slowly but proudly across the courtyard. She reaches the doorway, turns back.  If you'll excuse me, someone's waiting to help me make mango chutney. Why did no one tell me about that stuff?  Why? Are you thinking of applying for the job? She gestures for her wheelchair. Sonny rushes up with it. She sinks down.  That's enough exercise for one day.

description: Seven elderly Britons, for a variety of reasons, respond to an online ad and travel to Jaipur, India, where they find run-down hotel with a young, exuberant, and optimistic host. Evelyn Greenslade (Dame Judi Dench), newly widowed, wants a low-cost experience, Graham Dashwood (Tom Wilkinson) seeks a long-ago love, Douglas Ainslie (Bill Nighy) and Jean Ainslie (Dame Penelope Wilton) have lost their pension in a family investment, Muriel Donnelly (Dame Maggie Smith) needs cheap hip surgery, Madge Hardcastle (Celia Imrie) seeks a rich husband, and Norman Cousins (Ronald Pickup) is chasing women. India affects each in different ways, enchanting Douglas and Evelyn while driving Jean deeper into bitterness. Their host, young Sonny (Dev Patel), has dreams but little cash or skill; he also has a girlfriend whom his mother dismisses. Stories cross and discoveries await each one.—<jhailey@hotmail.com>
name: The Best Exotic Marigold Hotel
